pageProps.contentHtml:
Banach-Alaoglu, Hahn-Banach, Lp spaces, Urysohn subsequence principle

Let 1<p<∞1 < p < \infty1<p<∞ and let fn ⁣:R3→R\func{f_n}{\R^3}{\R}fn​:R3→R be a sequence of functions such that lim sup⁡n→∞∥fn∥Lp<∞\limsup_{n\to\infty}\norm{f_n}_{L^p} < \inftylimsupn→∞​∥fn​∥Lp​<∞. Show that if fnf_nfn​ converges almost everywhere, then fnf_nfn​ converges weakly in LpL^pLp.
Solution.

The condition on the LpL^pLp norms imply that sup⁡n∥fn∥Lp<∞\sup_n \norm{f_n}_{L^p} < \inftysupn​∥fn​∥Lp​<∞. Let 1<q<∞1 < q < \infty1<q<∞ be such that 1p+1q=1\frac{1}{p} + \frac{1}{q} = 1p1​+q1​=1 so that we may view Lp(R3)L^p\p{\R^3}Lp(R3) is the dual of Lq(R3)L^q\p{\R^3}Lq(R3).

Let {fnk}k\set{f_{n_k}}_k{fnk​​}k​ be a weakly convergent subsequence, i.e., fnk→ff_{n_k} \to ffnk​​→f weakly. By assumption, fnk→gf_{n_k} \to gfnk​​→g pointwise as well. We claim that f=gf = gf=g: if that were not the case, then by Hahn-Banach, there exists h∈Lq(R3)h \in L^q\p{\R^3}h∈Lq(R3) such that ∫(f−g)h>0\int \p{f - g}h > 0∫(f−g)h>0. But by Fatou's lemma and weak convergence,

0<∫(f−g)h=∫lim inf⁡k→∞(f−fnk)h≤lim inf⁡k→∞∫(f−fnk)h=∫(f−f)h=0,0 < \int \p{f - g}h = \int \liminf_{k\to\infty} \p{f - f_{n_k}}h \leq \liminf_{k\to\infty} \int \p{f - f_{n_k}}h = \int \p{f - f}h = 0,0<∫(f−g)h=∫k→∞liminf​(f−fnk​​)h≤k→∞liminf​∫(f−fnk​​)h=∫(f−f)h=0,

a contradiction. Hence, any weakly convergent subsequence of {fnk}k\set{f_{n_k}}_k{fnk​​}k​ converges weakly to the same limit. Now let {fnk}k\set{f_{n_k}}_k{fnk​​}k​ be any subsequence. This sequence is bounded in (Lq(R3))∗\p{L^q\p{\R^3}}^*(Lq(R3))∗, so by Banach-Alaoglu, it admits a weakly convergent subsequence, and by the argument above, this subsequence converges weakly to fff. Hence, any subsequence of {fn}n\set{f_n}_n{fn​}n​ admits a further subsequence which converges weakly to fff, and this implies that fn→ff_n \to ffn​→f weakly.

Indeed, if that were not the case, then there exists h∈Lq(R3)h \in L^q\p{\R^3}h∈Lq(R3) such that lim sup⁡n→∞∫fnh\limsup_{n\to\infty} \int f_nhlimsupn→∞​∫fn​h or lim inf⁡n→∞∫fnh\liminf_{n\to\infty} \int f_nhliminfn→∞​∫fn​h is not equal to ∫fh\int fh∫fh. Without loss of generality, suppose lim sup⁡n→∞∫fnh≠∫fh\limsup_{n\to\infty} \int f_nh \neq \int fhlimsupn→∞​∫fn​h=∫fh and so there exists a subsequence {fnk}k\set{f_{n_k}}_k{fnk​​}k​ such that

lim⁡k→∞∫fnkh=lim sup⁡n→∞∫fnh≠∫fh.\lim_{k\to\infty} \int f_{n_k}h = \limsup_{n\to\infty} \int f_nh \neq \int fh.k→∞lim​∫fnk​​h=n→∞limsup​∫fn​h=∫fh.

But this means that no further subsequence of {fnk}k\set{f_{n_k}}_k{fnk​​}k​ converges weakly to fff, which is impossible. This completes the proof.
